storyInfo: Gertrude extends an invitation to Czerny, in hopes he can perform his recently published Morgen und Abend at a funeral.

attributes.content: 'Any energy left? Shall we walk another lap of the Afterglow?'
'Hahah. You finally admit I'm in better shape than you, then?'
'The sun's low now. The wind at night... it's cold.'
'I know.'
He feebly smiles. His pallid face shines gilded gold in the twilight.
'But I'm going to keep walking until the sun's down. I'm going to walk from first light to last.'
'Deep upon my mind, I'll sear this place that raised me, and imprisoned me, for twenty years...'
'While I can still spurn it, sing of it, despise it, and miss it.'
'Because I know neither I, nor my music, will make it out of our little Afterglow again.'
'Promise me. Don't end up like me. Do better than I did... okay?'
Welcome.
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: Your eyes are ruddy. Did you just pass by the Afterglow Hall?
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: My sympathies.
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: Much appreciated, Strolloâ€”I mean, how rude of me, Gertrude.
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: That's alright. Not many are aware of this trivial preference of mine.
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: Even the retainers aren't used to addressing their Lehnsfrau by name. I've not been here long enough, simply put, and I and this city, this Spire, aren't too familiar yet.
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: Back to the topic, I just realize the inconvenience of this. With everyone busy today, you coming to the Cliffy Patio was the only option... Here, your medicine.
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: Danke.
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: The Spire guards didn't trouble you, I hope?
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: They intended to, until they read your note. Then they muttered something about it being 'outrageous' and stood aside.
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: There you have it. This Spire and I aren't just strangers, we're flat-out picking bones.
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: Not to mention, Czerny, as composer of Morgen und Abend, your name is known even beyond Vyseheim now. That's far more outrageous than an Infected or two entering the Cliffy Patio. Don't mind them.
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: (Sardonic laugh) Mind? It's not my first day as a commoner or an Infected... In any case, nobles like you are far too few. I must thank you again.
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: Don't rush to thank me, I didn't call you here just to collect your medicine. There was a favor I wanted to ask, too.
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: As long as it's within my power, then by all means.
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: I'm hoping you can perform Morgen und Abend for my brother's funeral.
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: I know it's somewhat of an ask. You'd have to arrange the flute and cello into solo piano, but even then...
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: No, I understand. You're utter strangers in a sense. Lehnsherr and subject, whatever that counts for.
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: But he... let me find the words. He didn't rule like my iron-fisted father before him. He was a vacillatory kind of man.
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: To put it unkindly, he was weak.
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: But because he was so irredeemably weak compared to Father, he was much less harmful. Not just to me, but to his own subjectsâ€”
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: Gertrude.
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: Yes?
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: No need to describe him so painstakingly. I know the feeling of losing a loved one.
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: I paid a visit to my mentor just before this. In your manner, she has little good to say about her daughter. She calls her stubborn, disobedient, unappreciative...
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: But once she has no more to say, she weeps too hard to breathe.
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: It is what it is to be vulnerable. Masking it by lambasting the dead hides nothing.
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: I know the Graf's funeral will draw great attendance from nobles, and you're quite used to striking two fowls with one stone, so my guess is...
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: Correct. Your patron will be inviting many music critics.
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: Your have quite a reputation already, but it's still not enough... Yes, let's be frank. It's far from enough. We must grab every opportunity we can to boost your fame.
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: Even your elder brother's funeral?
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: If it were a private remembrance, I would be glad to perform Morgen und Abend. However, before such stuck-up nobles and holier-than-thou critics...
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: It's you who needs the consolation at this time, Gertrude. Not them.
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: I know it doesn't take your fancy. When it comes to music, you're forever pure. I, though, am not you.
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: Those things you find insignificantâ€”money, fame, connections... I have to care. The artist can focus on one thing only, but the patron cannot.
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: Gertrude...
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: Think about it. Okay?
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: Suppertime, Mein Herr!
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: Mein Herrâ€”
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: Ursula, thank you, I heard you. Please lower your voice.
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: ...Have you been waiting for me this whole time?
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: That I have.
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: Tell me, what's the matter now? You were finally in good spirits for once...
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: Gertrude had a... request for me. She's asking I perform Morgen und Abend at her brother's funeral.
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: And how can you say no, when she's your very own patron?
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: ...They are laying a noble to rest in a public service, Ursula.
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: Performing Morgen und Abend, for me, is like... tearing off my own shell... displaying the most vulnerable part of me to someone else, hoping they'll understand, that they'll resonate with it.
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: Tell me to perform it for you, for Gertrude, for anyone in the Afterglow you like, and it would be my delight. Because I know you would understand me.
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: But those nobles, those critics... what will they understand? The technical prowess? Maybe they'll echo that one certain baffling review of the piece...
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: 'The composer's meager stature is so far short of the musical ambition as to unbalance the whole thing'?
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: Why should I have to make my vulnerability into a show for them? For the fame? The money?
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: Oh now now, slowly, Mein Herr, slow down. First we have some supper, yes?
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: Reports of the remnants' movements, gathering points of private arms... *sigh* Oh, dear brother, you.
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: Dame Strolloâ€”
attributes.name: Lachmann

attributes.content: What is going on? Youâ€”aren't those papers confidential?
attributes.name: Lachmann

attributes.content: All the more reason to feed them to the fireplace.
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: And by the way, Lachmann... it's been quite a few years since 'Herr Caster' planted you in Vyseheim.
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: Don't worry, 'he' was my father's handler, then my brother's, and now mine. I don't plan to change anything there.
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: ...I thank your graciousness, Dame Sâ€”Dame Gertrude, excuse me.
attributes.name: Lachmann

attributes.content: We need the funeral sorted before we make our next move. What's still unaccounted for?
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: I believe you know exactly what.
attributes.name: Lachmann

attributes.content: Those critics are gushing with the honor of being invited to a Graf's funeral, but should the musician himself fail to show...
attributes.name: Lachmann

attributes.content: Hah, yes.
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: He's a fool. Such a fool he'd turn away a silver platter of fame and fortune.
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: And that very foolishness is key. Morgen und Abend could only have been written in his longing for Fanny, not in mine for my dearest brother.
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: If you truly want this sentimental man fiddling in the palm of your hand, perhaps you should take things to the next level wit him personally...
attributes.name: Lachmann

attributes.content: Not one more inappropriate suggestion. He has no such interest in me. Getting him to see me as his generous patron, the most trustworthy of his friends, is enough.
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: But if...
attributes.name: Lachmann

attributes.content: You think all my efforts will be for naught on the off-chance he doesn't turn up, correct?
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: He will.
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: You have a backup plan?
attributes.name: Lachmann

attributes.content: 'Backup plan'. No, I simply know him well enough.
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: Or perhaps I should say, he's too blindingly simple of a person. One casual chat and you've already hit his deepest depths.
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: What do you mean by 'that was when you started waiting for me to eat'? Always I waited for you before supper, you hear.
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: I remember one time Fanny came to tell me there was an error in one of my counterpoint exercises, and I pushed away my plate and rushed right to my mentor's home to quarrel with her until the dead of night...
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: I came home on an empty stomach to find the table cleared, nothing left.
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: How was I supposed to know they'd have no food that day, eh. Besides, didn't I bring over m'own catering for her the next day?
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: ...On which Fanny burnt her tongue.
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: And you almost dropped m'roast potatoes on the floor.
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: The potato soup's still warm, now, have another bowl.
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: Hrm.
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: Who's there? Let yourself in, it's open.
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: Come on in, come on in!
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: So much easier to find your place now, Frau Ursula.
attributes.name: Food Stall Owner

attributes.content: The Herr fought for that, y'see.
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: Hahah, he's fought for much more than himself!
attributes.name: Food Stall Owner

attributes.content: Congrats to you all on the new home, and congrats to you, Czerny, it feels like yesterday you were a little brat and now you've done something we could never dream of and become talk of the town!
attributes.name: Food Stall Owner

attributes.content: *clicks tongue* What a splendiferous place... What's this, a bathtub?
attributes.name: Food Stall Owner

attributes.content: I haven't seen one of these in years, now. Frau, how's it to use?
attributes.name: Food Stall Owner

attributes.content: You're asking? M'bone joints used to itch each time it rained, oh, terrible, I couldn't stand it. Now with all the Herr's done, I dip in the tub and m'body comes out sixty years younger!
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: You see that, Czerny, Frau Ursula's life is never better! That's you, you made it happen!
attributes.name: Food Stall Owner

attributes.content: Mrm... mm.
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: Here, take this! Fine wine, the finest, they love it all day in the Cliffy Patio. If you knew how long it took me to get it from that asshole running the cafe...
attributes.name: Food Stall Owner

attributes.content: You're too kind, too kind. We're havin' supper right now, stay and have some, ja?
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: No need.
attributes.name: Food Stall Owner

attributes.content: There was this whole party of people the other day, couldn't tell you where from, come 'in search of the place where the great composer Czerny was born'.
attributes.name: Food Stall Owner

attributes.content: At that very same time I was drumming up customers with my accordion, and whoof, good day for the ol' fried sauerkraut stand. If I ever get business like that again, oh, you bet I'm there.
attributes.name: Food Stall Owner

attributes.content: Right, you get on with it!
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: Mein Herr, what's the matter with you? Someone drops by, and he's here to housewarm you. You don't even say hello?
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: I was quite a hassle to him before, so it's just... a little awkward for me.
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: Hassle? Oh, that fight, you mean, the one you had.
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: *clears throat*.
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: Old news, old. You told him sorry, and you heard him, you were just caring too much, that's all. Him, he holds nothing against you.
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: That was...
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: I know, you're not too good with words. The whole Afterglow knows, ja? We know.
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: But I'll tell you what you do have, now. It's too much temper.
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: FrÃ¤ulein Fanny, when she couldn't taste the food she ate? She didn't know up from down she was so sick, that's why she thought, gosh, they must be doing it to me on purpose. Then you come along and get carried away with it, why?
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: Scared the daylights out of me when you stormed up to his stand, never saw you so furious in all my lifeâ€”
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: ...My bad, my bad. Eat, go on, let's eat.
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: Ursula.
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: What is it, Mein Herr?
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: Would you say, if I went to that funeral, then more of that... business, that the Herr mentioned, would come in?
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: If I should show my weakness to the ones who don't give a shit about our fates, to let them scrutinize me, then would the Afterglow... have a few more houses with bathtubs, maybe?
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: Mein Herr...
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: No, this is wrong. This isn't how music should be. At least not my music.
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: But...
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: 'Because I know neither I, nor my music, will make it out of our little Afterglow again.'
'Promise me. Don't end up like me. Do better than I did... okay?'
Mein Herr, where're you off to?
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: Gertrude.
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: The sooner I accept her invitation, the sooner I can start arranging Morgen und Abend for solo piano.
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: Time flies.
The previous Graf Strollo's funeral is already halfway through. The performance is set to begin.

Czerny lifts his head, looking into the distance. The lofty buildings of the Cliffy Patio enter his vision, yet in his mind's eye, he sees that afternoon with Fanny, passing by the Afterglow Hall again and again.
He gives an imperceptible bow to the crowd, seats himself, and begins to perform.
They had an Infected play for this funeral?
attributes.name: Scathing Noble

attributes.content: Obviously she's seizing on her brother's death for the chance to sell more records.
attributes.name: Acerbic Noble

attributes.content: A piano solo? I highly doubt whether a single piano grants him enough to evoke both a flute and a cello's manners at once.
attributes.name: Blathering Critic

attributes.content: The musician's ears are sharp. He hears every ill-willed voice picking away at him, before the performance is even truly underway.
He bites at his tongue in regret, but it's too late to stop playing now.
He's already heard everything, but he needs to force himself not to hear anything.
The melody trickles through the grounds. The noise doesn't subside, and yet, it gradually begins to fade away from him.
Morgen und Abend.
From first light to last.
If a flute is clarity, light, expanse, like an unbounded sunrise atop the hill, then the piano's morning sun is addled by a shawl of mist.
Sunlight bathes the earth in equal measure, never dwindling for the parched, nor strengthening for the clouded.
The wisps of chill emanating from the first light feel almost ruthless.
...Bold arrangement.
attributes.name: Silent Critic

attributes.content: I still don't think it's quite on the mark. Can you really call this morning sun? What could a morning sun like this possibly illuminate?
attributes.name: Blathering Critic

attributes.content: Perhaps nothing at all.
attributes.name: Silent Critic

attributes.content: He's quite engrossed.
attributes.name: Scathing Noble

attributes.content: I'd posit it's the first he's ever performed for so much nobility. He'd do well to seize the chance.
attributes.name: Acerbic Noble

attributes.content: But if you ask me, Strolloâ€”and not the one flitting around the attendance, I mean the one in the coffinâ€”he's had the short end of the stick.
attributes.name: Acerbic Noble

attributes.content: The man spent so long living in his father's shadow, and he could barely come into power himself before illness whisked him right back out. To boot, an Infected playing at his funeral.
attributes.name: Acerbic Noble

attributes.content: From first light to last.
A hammer can never shudder the listener's heartstrings as the bow does, stirring the doleful scarlet shadows of the setting sun.
And so, he chooses to perform the most ordinary afterglow one could know.
The sun is setting soon. It's time for us to go to sleep.
Hurried gasps. The scent of bed. That orange ceiling. The scattered stars glimpsed through deep blue curtains.
At its jet-black nadir, the night holds the departed close. The light still lingers. The musician, ignoring them all, performs that deep, shivering green where light and dark intertwine.
Violent yet tranquil, profound yet mundane. The most ordinary of forever partings.
Graf Strollo, you tragedy... *sigh*.
attributes.name: Acerbic Noble

attributes.content: Timid, shrunken bastard. Laughed at his own words as if apologizing for everything he said, even after succeeding the title.
attributes.name: Acerbic Noble

attributes.content: The last time I saw him, he gave me the wrong gift. I jeered at him to my heart's content... And now, damn it all, it's like he's still there, laughing along.
attributes.name: Acerbic Noble

attributes.content: What drives me to do that, my godâ€”
attributes.name: Acerbic Noble

attributes.content: ...Shh.
attributes.name: Scathing Noble

attributes.content: (Sniffs)
attributes.name: Acerbic Noble

attributes.content: From first light to last.
The sun climbs up in its track, up to its apex, so high as to steal the breath from you. Then in gentle leisure it descends, until the murk of twilight, until it sinks into the earth.
In the face of the sun, we are insignificant, exposed, our wealth of emotion our greatest treasure, one amounting to so, so little.
If we could tarry just a little longer in this mortal coil, could we see the pain vanished, the wrinkles smoothed, the love we've lost made young by the dusk of rising east and dawn of setting west?
But we are no more than motes in the confines of time. In the end, we part.
A thorough and achingly open parting.
The final note disappears into the late rays' winds.
They blow it away from Vyseheim, to some place far beyond the eye, and only then do the whispers finally surface again.
Now these murmurings are solemn and restrained, interspersed with low sobs.
...You know who I'm reminded of? My uncle. A veteran who retired from the field, terrible temper. Never much humored me. And then eventually he became senile.
attributes.name: Scathing Noble

attributes.content: I visited him once before he passed. Just so happened to find him burning his things in the garden. The wind came and carried away all that paper ash, like grey snow falling into the sky.
attributes.name: Scathing Noble

attributes.content: Czerny, Czerny...
attributes.name: Acerbic Noble

attributes.content: My god, there's nothing fair about a man's fate. How could he have been born here? How could he be an Infected?
attributes.name: Acerbic Noble

attributes.content: You're quiet.
attributes.name: Silent Critic

attributes.content: (Sniffs) I... *sigh*... what else can I say? What am I fit to say?
attributes.name: Blathering Critic

attributes.content: Once I'm home, once I've calmed down, I'll write a mild review. You know, that's highest praise coming from me. But for nowâ€”
attributes.name: Blathering Critic

attributes.content: (Takes a deep breath)
attributes.name: Blathering Critic

attributes.content: Let's talk about something else. Have you noticed Herr Ed? He's the most esteemed of the critics Dame Strollo invited here, but I haven't seen him at all.
attributes.name: Blathering Critic

attributes.content: Dame Strollo was just looking for him at the burial site.
attributes.name: Silent Critic

attributes.content: Just? While Herr Czerny was playing?
attributes.name: Blathering Critic

attributes.content: Yes.
attributes.name: Silent Critic

attributes.content: Czerny slowly lets out a very pent-up breath.
His ears are sharp. He's heard everything, the voices flummoxed by prejudice, yet shaken by art... by their own vulnerability.
He wipes the tears from his face, and incidentally catches sight of Gertrude.
Herr Ed, I count my blessings that you suffered no misfortune while lost in the Afterglow alleys.
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: The onus lies with me, that I had you so graciously lead me out, and miss Herr Czerny's performance in the process.
attributes.name: Esteemed Critic

attributes.content: I wouldn't be so sure. Didn't we hear it, even from where we were? What beautiful music.
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: Gertrude forgets to hide her formality smile as she turns her head, forgets to switch to one of grief, and that is how she makes eye contact with Czerny.
Once she takes notice of how incongruous the musician's red eyes and her own expression are, only then does she realize she's made a huge mistake.
Would that she could take it back, she thinks, as she maintains the smile on her face, leaves the critic it was meant for behind, and quickly paces over to him.
As she expected, Czerny is also walking up to meet her.
What is Czerny doing? Striding right over to Dame Strollo? Not one acknowledgement for the audience?
attributes.name: Blathering Critic

attributes.content: ...As is fair. They must have a lot to talk over.
attributes.name: Blathering Critic

attributes.content: This... is how you mourn your brother?
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: ...The artist can focus on one thing only, but the patron cannot.
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: The setting sun hangs west. Both take pains not to look at the other's face again.
Don't.
attributes.name: Gertrude

attributes.content: ...Fine. It's your turn to grieve for him.
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: Czerny hurriedly leaves the Afterglow plaza. No greeting. No stopping. No one enters his eyes.
Mein Herr, letter for you.
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: From who?
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: ...GrÃ¤fin Strollo.
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: You haven't talked for a month. What if...
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: An invitation card... and a penned letter?
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: You want to invite me a second time, Gertrude... Dame Strollo?
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: No, first, let's see what she wrote.
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: Find you well, how do you do... this is hollow rubbish.
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: Wait, what is this in her postscript...
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.text: 'I won't apologize for the funeral, nor for never grieving over my brother. I apologize that I cheated you.'
'If you'd believe it, I came to realize afterwards I only accomplished one thing.'
'I had an Infected perform a piece at Graf Strollo's funeral, sending my dearest Strollo family... 'best wishes'. Ridiculous, isn't it?'
'...I'm astonished I just tacked on such carelessly offensive words.'
'It seems, in the end, we're not the same.'

attributes.content: Gertrude, you absolute...
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: This... isn't even her invitation. Is this... a tour?
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: A tour?
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: Critics and nobles all wanted me to perform in their cities after that funeral, so she went and drew up a 'tour'...
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: 'The artist can focus on one thing only, but the patron cannot,' you say?
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: ...*sigh*.
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: Ursula, what do you think about the tour?
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: An Infected on tour... I can't imagine how it might turn out, but I'm sure it wouldn't be like on holidays.
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: What an understatement. I'd practically be an exotic sideshow animal...
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: But I must go.
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: What for?
attributes.name: Ursula

attributes.content: I simply believe the sound of my strings, an Infected's strings... is enough to cross the widest gap, and plunge into those nobles' hearts.
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: Even if I'm uncompensated, even if I'll be some rare creature to gawk at, just put a piano in my cage...
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: Even if all I have is a metal stick to strike at my bars, I'll be more than willing.
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: Just as Czerny expected, the tour of an Infected musician is akin to an exotics display.
Even now, on the very last stop...
The streets have been emptied to allow this Infected to walk to the venue on his own. None are willing to walk with the Infected, save for an impatient bodyguard.
Out of nowhere, in the faintest strains, he hears the most familiar music. It comes from a roadside garden.
Morgen und Abend?!
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: Don't stop! Move!
attributes.name: Indifferent Noble

attributes.content: Mein Herr, whose garden is...
attributes.name: Czerny

attributes.content: The Markgraf's family cemetery! Move it, move!
attributes.name: Indifferent Noble

attributes.content: Czerny begins his stride, as he lifts his head to the sky.
The city's overcast almost resembles the night sky. The irregular schedule of the tour has messed up his body clock. He just wants to sleep.
He barely has any energy left.
But still he'll keep this ailing body going, to make another lap of this dwarfing mortal coil they call life, around and around, onward and onward.
He'll spurn, sing, despise, miss...
From first light, to last.
